passage_list.text: For years in my twenties, I wore the wrong shoe size—a 7 when I am actually closer to an 8. I did not know this until I discovered a bunion on my left foot and began ranting to my boyfriend, T, about how all shoes are uncomfortable, how my toes pinched and heels bled, how early hominins may have been right to squelch their naked toes in the soft earth. T stared at me with polite confusion. “I don’t think shoes are supposed to be uncomfortable,” they eventually responded. They suggested I try on a pair of their shoes, a size up from what I wore. When I slipped my feet inside the shoe, I felt nothing: no squeeze, no pinch, just space. I walked around our apartment, wobbly until I wasn’t. This revelation now seems mortifyingly obvious. But I had become so inured to my ambient discomfort that I assumed everyone felt this way—inconvenienced and constricted by the friction between our bodies and what we use to conceal them.

I have always been disillusioned with the limits of human growth. Even as babies we resemble our future selves, our skin merely stretching, furring, and wrinkling as we age. But insects have a much more fantastic notion of growing up. Their rigid exoskeletons cannot expand with growth, so they molt. They shed old skins and form new ones that are billowing and soft, able to hold more body than before. Some insects like praying mantises undergo transformations with some bodily continuity. They hatch from eggs into tiny wingless adults called nymphs. Nymphs molt into more nymphs, growing larger and sprouting wing buds until the final molt, when the adult emerges like a new, green leaf. But the more famous kind of metamorphosis is more total—that quintessential transmogrification from a caterpillar to chrysalis to butterfly. Born as an egg, growing up as a larva, congealing into a pupa, and unfurling into a winged adult.

It’s idyllic to think that all transitions could be this easy: one form sliding cleanly into another, implying a kind of progression. What could be more aspirational than wings? But molting is no easy feat. A transforming insect cannot eat. Sometimes it cannot move. Mayfly larvae must stop breathing for up to an hour as their exoskeletons slip off. The firebrat, a tiny torpedo that feeds on bookbindings, molts as many as sixty times in the few years it lives. Even for insects, there is no one way to transform. These changes can be creeping; some caterpillars already have tiny wings enclosed, unseen within their bodies. Most caterpillars carry no trace of their past selves after molts. Many will eat the skin they shed, swallowing a past silhouette. But some species cannot bear to part with their old selves. In Australia and New Zealand, a moth called the gum-leaf skeletonizer hoards its old heads, stacking them atop its current head like de-nested Matryoshka dolls. These headpieces grow taller with each molt, tapering into a tower of dead heads that can be nearly half as tall as the caterpillar is long. The display is certainly grotesque. But the many-headed tiara may help the caterpillar avoid the jaws of a predator, offering the gift of a more threatening aura and, perhaps, an extra chance of escape.

Maybe this is why I, too, hoard remnants of my past selves. My apartment teems with objects I will never wear again but am afraid to throw away: a sequined chartreuse dress, an unopened vial of hibiscus perfume, a pair of crocodilian heels in a dusty box. Maybe Sabrina—a name that conjures a mold I often do not fit, a name that many of my friends do not use—is also a head I will cast off when I am ready. Maybe hoarding these things makes molting easier, a way of holding on to my past selves. Maybe I will find my way back to them in new ways.

Like all caterpillars, the gum-leaf skeletonizer caterpillar eventually stiffens into a pupa, the protective cocoon in which it will dissolve its body into unrecognizable goo. Here, it reshapes itself into an adult, cells dividing into wings, antennae, legs, and genitals. If you cut open the cocoon, the once-caterpillar would be little more than soup. But if you give it time, something as miraculous as a moth might emerge—silky brown wings corrugated like tree bark.

For a few months now, each night before bed, I smear my skin with an ooze that has the power to reshape my body. At first, it felt like nothing was happening, my human form as rigid as ever. But lately, I can feel myself shifting: thrumming gravel in my voice, pimples on my chin, a pinkish bulge that is now larger than an almond, a newly incandescent desire for sex. But unlike something shielded in a cocoon, my soft body is out in the world. Everyone around me is witness to my transformation, whether they know it or not. I karaoke through my voice cracks, hovering between octaves in search of the safest place to land.

In truth, I do not know where that will be. But I know this: I deserve to be comfortable. I deserve to feel at home in my body and what surrounds it. Because in spite of all the voice cracks and pimples and other embarrassments of a second puberty, I have never felt lighter, more free. Because molting is an act of love. It is a promise that you will grow into yourself and your wild and unexpected future. It is a promise to trust the process, that even mired in goo and guts, something like bliss may wait on the other side.

questions.question: What is the main focus of the passage?

options.A: The discomfort of wearing the wrong shoe size
options.B: The history of early hominins and their footwear
options.C: The relationship between the narrator and their boyfriend

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the narrator’s realization about wearing the wrong shoe size and the discomfort it caused.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the central subject of the passage and avoid being distracted by secondary details.

questions.question: As used in the passage, what does the word 'molting' most nearly mean?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'molting' refers to the process of shedding old skin to allow for growth, as described in the passage.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to infer the meaning of words that describe biological processes.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the gum-leaf skeletonizer caterpillar?

options.A: It uses its old heads to intimidate predators.
options.B: It eats its old skin to hide evidence of molting.
options.C: It molts fewer times than other caterpillars.
options.D: It does not undergo a complete metamorphosis.

questions.explanation: The passage suggests that the gum-leaf skeletonizer caterpillar stacks its old heads to create a threatening appearance, which may help it avoid predators.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for implicit information that is not directly stated but can be logically inferred from the text.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the narrator’s reflection on hoarding objects?

options.A: To explain their attachment to past identities
options.B: To criticize their inability to let go of material possessions
options.C: To compare their behavior to that of insects
options.D: To emphasize the importance of minimalism

questions.explanation: The narrator reflects on hoarding objects as a way of holding on to past identities and selves, suggesting a deeper emotional connection to these items.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to the author's or narrator's intent when analyzing reflections or personal anecdotes.

questions.question: Which choice best describes the process of metamorphosis in the gum-leaf skeletonizer caterpillar?

options.A: It involves a complete dissolution of the body before reshaping.
options.B: It is a gradual process with no significant changes.
options.C: It occurs without the need for a protective cocoon.
options.D: It results in the caterpillar retaining its old heads.

questions.explanation: The passage describes how the caterpillar dissolves its body into goo within a cocoon before reshaping into an adult, highlighting the transformative nature of metamorphosis.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze the process or sequence of events described in the text to understand its key features.

questions.question: Which piece of evidence best supports the idea that the narrator’s transformation is ongoing?

options.A: The narrator smears their skin with an ooze each night.
options.B: The narrator’s voice cracks during karaoke.
options.C: The narrator feels a newly incandescent desire for sex.
options.D: The narrator’s body is out in the world during the transformation.

questions.explanation: The narrator’s voice cracks during karaoke suggest that their transformation is still in progress, as these are signs of ongoing physical changes.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify direct textual evidence that supports the main idea or specific claims in the passage.

questions.question: How does the narrator’s reflection on molting relate to the overall theme of the article?

options.A: It emphasizes the difficulty of letting go of past identities.
options.B: It highlights the narrator’s desire to remain unchanged.
options.C: It connects the narrator’s personal growth to the process of metamorphosis.
options.D: It suggests that the narrator regrets their transformation.

questions.explanation: The narrator’s reflection on molting connects their personal growth and transformation to the biological process of metamorphosis, reinforcing the article’s theme of change and self-discovery.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how different parts of the text connect to support or explain a central theme or idea.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the narrator’s attitude toward their transformation?

options.A: They are fearful and resistant to change.
options.B: They are optimistic and embrace the process.
options.C: They are indifferent to the physical changes.
options.D: They are frustrated by the lack of progress.

questions.explanation: The narrator expresses a sense of freedom and lightness despite the challenges of transformation, indicating an optimistic and accepting attitude.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use descriptive language and emotional cues in the text to infer the narrator’s attitude or perspective.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the narrator’s statement, “molting is an act of love”?

options.A: To emphasize the emotional aspect of transformation
options.B: To criticize the physical discomfort of molting
options.C: To compare molting to romantic relationships
options.D: To suggest that molting is a selfish process

questions.explanation: The narrator’s statement highlights the emotional and self-affirming nature of transformation, framing it as an act of self-love and growth.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider the broader context and implications of specific statements or reflections in the text.

questions.question: Which choice best maintains the grammatical and logical coherence of the following sentence? “Because in spite of all the voice cracks and pimples and other embarrassments of a second puberty, I have never felt lighter, more free.”

options.B: Because in spite of all the voice cracks and pimples and other embarrassments of a second puberty, I have never felt lighter, more free
options.C: Because in spite of all the voice cracks and pimples and other embarrassments of a second puberty I have never felt lighter, more free.
options.D: Because in spite of all the voice cracks and pimples and other embarrassments of a second puberty, I have never felt lighter more free.

questions.explanation: The original sentence is grammatically correct and logically coherent, with proper punctuation and structure.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure that sentences maintain proper grammatical structure and logical flow, especially when dealing with complex ideas.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning or analyze complex text structures.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas and details.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text.
